Question 23) Chernobyl's nuclear accident brutally reveals the boundaries of humanity's technical-scientific powers and the "marches" that "nature" can reserve us. It is evident that more collective management imposes itself to guide sciences and techniques toward more human purposes. The text deals with the technical-scientific apparatus and its consequences for humanity, proposing that this development
A) Define your projects from collective interests.
B) Guide by economic interests, prescribed by the logic of the market.
C) Prioritize the evolution of technology, appropriating nature.
D) Promote the separation between nature and technological society.
E) Have its own management, with the objective of better appropriation of nature.
